tit.cmt: Gosechimai→Gosechi no Maiとしました。(*五節舞、五節の舞どちらも「ごせちのまい」と読むと思われます)

sen.j: 五節舞、五節の舞（ごせちのまい）とは、大嘗祭や新嘗祭に行われる豊明節会で、大歌所の別当が歌う大歌に合わせて舞われる、4～5人の舞姫によって舞われる舞。
sen.e: Gosechimai (Gosechi no mai) was a dance that was danced, on the occasion of Toyoakari no sechie (one of the ceremonies at a seasonal holiday) held on the days of Daijo-sai festival (a festival to celebrate the succession of an emperor) and Niiname-sai festival (ceremonial offering by the Emperor of newly-harvested rice to deities), by four to five dancers to the song sung by the chief of Outadokoro (an organization that provided the education and management of ancient Japanese music).

Gosechimai (Gosechi no mai) was a dance that took place during a Toyoakari no sechie (a ceremony at a seasonal holiday) which was held at Daijo-sai festivals (a festival to celebrate the succession of an emperor) and Niiname-sai festivals (a ceremonial offering by the Emperor of newly-harvested rice to deities). In the dance, there would be four to five women dancing to music sung by the chief of the Outadokoro (an organization that provided the education and management of ancient Japanese music).

Dancers were selected in a manner of two daughters from noble families and two from the zuryo (the head of provincial government) or tenjobito (a high-ranking courtier allowed into the Imperial Court). Having a daughter selected for the dance was considered an honor for the family.

sen.j: このため、天武天皇は大陸の礼楽思想を取り入れる意図をもって五節舞を考案したとする見方もある（なお、聖武天皇が元正上皇のために孝謙天皇（孝謙天皇）に五節舞を舞わせた際に、天皇が上皇に対して「天武天皇が天下統治のために礼と楽を整備するために五節舞を考え出された」と述べている（『続日本紀』天平15年5月辛丑条））。
